contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced stub|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} A '''lysis buffer''' is a [[buffer solution]] used for the purpose of [[lysis|lysing]] cells for use in [[molecular biology]] experiments that analyze the compounds of the cells (e.g. [[western blot]]). There are many different types of lysis buffer that can be applied, depending on what analysis the [[cell lysate]] will be used for (e.g. red blood cell lysis buffer). Generally, lysis buffers contain [[tris-HCl]], [[EDTA]], [[EGTA (chemical)|EGTA]], [[Sodium dodecyl sulfate|SDS]], [[deoxycholate]], [[Triton X-100|tritonX]] and/or [[NP-40]]. In some cases the buffer may also contain [[NaCl]] (150 [[mM]]). In studies like [[DNA fingerprinting]] the lysis buffer is used for DNA isolation. [[Dish soap]] can be used in a pinch to break down the cell and nuclear membranes, allowing the DNA to be released. Other such lysis buffers include the proprietary [[Qiagen]] product [[Buffer P2]]. [[Radioimmunoprecipitation_assay_buffer|RIPA buffer]] is another commonly used lysis buffer for [[immunoprecipitation]] and general protein extraction from cells and tissues. {{DEFAULTSORT:Lysis Buffer}} [[Category:Laboratory techniques]] [[Category:Cell biology]] [[Category:DNA]] {{Biology-stub}}
